data.text: @VictimOfMaths @UKHSA Very big caveat!  Aware of a lot of reinfections with much smaller gaps (some where timing suggests Delta then BA.1 and some that look like BA.1 then BA.2).
@VictimOfMaths Not saying it is the explanation, but all the recent reinfections around me would fly under the radar as <90 days.
@VictimOfMaths If the reinfection means people catching the virus more than once, the recent rise in cases must be due to reinfection.
@VictimOfMaths omicron. Not sure if that makes sense. Hope so

@VictimOfMaths depends on the criteria used. If they are thinking it's only a re infection after 90 days then it won't tick that box. But it might show as there is an infection. Similar thing with it bouncing around families. Only happened since Xmas so presume that's

@VictimOfMaths - ve lateral flows and about a week in between +ve lft. They were finding that school kids were bouncing the virus around the class. Whether that would be picked up as a re infection in the data or not

@VictimOfMaths So I presume the 90 days you talk about ties in with the 90 days between positive pcr tests.
I phoned 119 in Feb and they said that you should take a +ve lateral flow as covid even if pcr negative. They'd had a lot of calls from parents of school kids who'd had a couple of
@UncleJo46902375 @VictimOfMaths @UKHSA Certainly is. I know 3 people who were reinfected within 8 weeks (one at 6 weeks). 90 days is skewing the reality
@VictimOfMaths When reinfections are happening within 30-60 days after prior infection, 90 days reinfections mean nothing... The metric is wrong!
@VictimOfMaths BA2 is getting those BA1 didn't.
